p: In general, a disease transmission system is composed of a set of species that interact in hosting and vectoring a pathogen in space [ 14], and all the component species have a unique biogeography related to its ecological niche (i.e. those conditions appropriate for its survival and reproduction), interactions with other species and accessible areas over time [ 14, 15]. Therefore, a large part of disease transmission risk corresponds to the intersection of the distributional areas of the species involved [ 14].
